Topic.Title: Understanding Einhorn's proposal

Message.Msg: Lets be clear, under Einhorn's proposal Apple will not receive or distribute cash in any shape or form whatsoever other than a 4% annual dividend to the preferreds. I altered his proposal in my example by pretending the preferreds where actually issued to the open market for cash proceeds. I did this solely to make it easier for some people to understand the substance of what Einhorn is proposing. So people could more readily follow the math behind it. Einhorn's actual proposal is the right way to do it. First and foremost, it doesn't involve cash other than the preferred dividend payment. There is no actual one time dividend to common holders. So no tax. However, if the common holder decides to sell his preferred, then he will pay some form of tax assuming it is not in some sort of qualified account. That's for each shareholder to decide both on the amount and timing of sale. They retain control of their tax situation and can choose to defer it as long as they choose. Second, Einhorn's proposal does not alter the operations of the company at all. And last, it does not change control of the company among common stock shareholders. All of this does not change the intrinsic value of the business. It will force the market to recognize that value but it neither adds nor detracts from it. Apple will be the same company the day after as it was the day before. Management will still have a 137 billion war chest and upwards of 15 billion per year to add to that. Nobody gets harmed save for short sellers and certain option holders, but that is not our concern because they are not legitimate stakeholders. Employee options can be adjusted and repriced. It's an idea. I believe it's a good idea, but again it doesn't change the value of the business.

Message.Title: Apple Hires TV Guy..
Message.Msg: A little late doncha think? By the time he designs something, TV will be obsolete. lol Apple CEO Tim Cook likes to talk about his company’s plans for Apple TV as “pulling the string to see where it leads them.” It seems it may have led them to hire an expert in flat panel televisions. In a report this week, industry group the OLED Association noted that Apple had hired away James (Jueng-jil) Lee from LG Display. At LG he was a research fellow working on creating a printed organic light-emitting diode (OLED) based television. And perhaps more importantly, he’s an expert in LCD production: before he was at LG he started new LCD product lines at Samsung and was heavily involved in their LCD research efforts. Lee is ”no doubt more knowledgeable about OLEDs that any of Apple’s current staff, which is known to be quite strong,” according to the OLED Association. Apple has refused to give any information about whether it’s getting into the television market. Cook has said several times that TV is “a market that’s been left behind” and for Apple is “an area of intense interest,” but that’s as far as he’ll go. Hiring an expert in getting a new display line up and going definitely seems more like action than mere “interest.”

Message.Msg: Aswath Damodaran isn't crazy about David Einhorn's Apple preferred stock proposal. "Issuing preferred stock will not add value to the company," the finance prof. argues. Moreover, while such a move could lift shares by removing investor fears of never seeing much of the cash Apple generates, regular dividends and/or buybacks could do the same. Nonetheless, Damodaran is glad Einhorn is "rocking the boat," as it "opens the door to a healthy discussion about how Apple should deal with its large and growing cash balance."

Message.Title: BlackBerry 10 maps even worse than Apple Maps
Message.Msg: Among the complaints being registered, there is absolutely no satellite view, let alone a Street View alternative. Users also get no public transit directions, which makes the lack of apps in the store that much more annoying. BlackBerry chose not to partner with a review service of any kind, meaning there are no reviews attached to map search results like you’d see in other apps. The missing features are irksome, but it also looks like the app has trouble with basic functionality. Local venues often fail to pop up in search results, but chain stores and landmarks come up no problem. If you’re trying to find that little corner deli you like, good luck. The app also can’t show you directions from anywhere but your current location. Apple famously misplaced entire cities in its mapping app, but it’s unclear if BB10 will suffer similar issues on that front

I truly do not understand given these facts, how AAPL does not scream buy to any potential investor.

Analysts wrote: “After Apple released HD iPad in 2012, it reduced the pricing of the iPad 2 16 GB to $399. The Kindle Fire and Nook tablets were launched at $199 and $249 respectively and saw loads of buyers lining up for the extremely cheap tablets. As the tablet market matures and includes more price-conscious consumers, Apple Inc. may be forced to bring down the prices of the future iPads as well.

Message.Title: Was AAPL oversold?
Message.Msg: That may be. But it had been over bought and over pumped in the first place. People forget "the large number". Everyone has witnessed the China miraculous economy in the past 20 years.. it started with 5%/year, 10%/year, 15%/year, 20%/year, 25%/year then back to 20%/year, 15%/year, 10%/year, 7%/year.. That is typical growth curve when it has done everything right. You can't expect #2 economy to grow 20%/year, any more. Same thing for apple, it is going to be very difficult for aapl to make 50B/year. Considering its mature products and competition landscape. In face, me not even sure that using China growth for aapl is a good example.. High end smart phones market has matured. The sudden frenzy (helped by media hype, apple II computer did the same) makes people think this is "eco-system". Me still thinks that smart phone prices will start to fall as technology becomes mature and technical barriers reduced. Tablets are the same thing. Me almost can tell you that AAPL will have multi-year decline. The quickest smart phone growth is in the low end range because it is 1/3-1/4 of the high end price. These phones are pretty good, if you are not a heavy user... Is apple dead? Well, is MSFT dead? NVDA has half of the market cap in cash, so? In fact, due to potential price/margin erosion, AAPL has higher risk shrinking than MSFT. AAPL may not stay above 400$ very long.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Ultimately, I agree with the position taken by Fool analyst Andrew Tonner, who believes that while Einhorn's suggestion is unlikely to carry the day, it calls attention to how favorably priced the stock is at current levels. The company is one big product away from rocketing back to greatness and a significantly higher stock price. Even if that product does not come, or is slow to, the company is sitting on so much cash that it is hard not to like your chances with the name anyway. Even with the late-day pop, the stock carries a 2.3% dividend yield, a P/E ratio of 10.6 and the title of largest technology company on earth. With the strong cash flow data, a huge correction under its belt, and no lack of upside, Apple shares look attractive.

Topic.Title: Why would CALpers issue a statment in support of Proposal 2?

Message.Msg: From Apple's statement:...As a part of our efforts to further enhance corporate governance and serve our shareholders’ best interests, Proposal #2 in our proxy includes some recommended changes to our articles of incorporation. These changes were recommended independently of Greenlight’s proposal and would not preclude Apple from adopting their concept. Contrary to Greenlight’s statements, adoption of Proposal #2 would not prevent the issuance of preferred stock. Currently, Apple’s articles of incorporation provide for the issuance of “blank check” preferred stock by the Board of Directors without shareholder approval. If Proposal #2 is adopted, our shareholders would have the right to approve the issuance of preferred stock. As such, Proposal #2 has the support of many of our shareholders.

Message.Title: The Best Thing Apple Can Do With its Cash is to Buy Local Corp with a Market Cap of only 36 Million and Revenues of 100 Million and an
Message.Msg: Adjusted Net Income of 5 million in 2013: The Best Thing Apple Can Do With its Cash By Andrés Cardenal - February 9, 2013|Andrés is a member of The Motley Fool Blog Network -- entries represent the personal opinions of our bloggers and are not formally edited. Hedge fund manager David Einhorn has made a lot of waves recently by urging Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) to put its cash to better use. Einhorn is right in pointing put the fact that the company is mismanaging its assets by keeping an enormous amount of cash in low-return investments as opposed to unlocking that value in the benefit of shareholders. His proposal regarding that money is certainly smart and innovative, but I have a better idea: Apple should simply implement a big fat buyback program. The Cash Problem Apple has more than $137 billion in balance sheet cash; this is more than enough to go through any difficulties that may arise in the future, especially considering that the company generates tons of free cash flows on a quarterly basis. This is an inefficient use of the shareholders' capital, and it needs to be worked out.

Message.Title: Statement by Apple
Message.Msg: By early last year, Apple’s cash balance had built to a point beyond what we needed to run our business and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities, so we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years. As of next week we will have executed $10 billion of that plan. We find ourselves in the fortunate position of continuing to generate large amounts of cash, including $23 billion in cash flow from operations in the last quarter alone. Apple’s management team and Board of Directors have been in active discussions about returning additional cash to shareholders. As part of our review, we will thoroughly evaluate Greenlight Capital’s current proposal to issue some form of preferred stock. We welcome Greenlight’s views and the views of all of our shareholders. We remain committed to having an ongoing dialogue with our shareholders to get perspectives around return of capital and driving shareholder value.

Message.Title: Apple pipeline is amazing
Message.Msg: They will bring out: iTV is a huge deal with content sales and control. The new technology in the TV will be so revolutionary to allow it to sells tens of millions of units in the first few years. Content & advertising revenue will add greatly to the bottom line as well. iWatch will be an ultra-cool iOS companion. It will work with the iPod, iPhone, and iTV. It will be the easiest way to control and get information from all your i-Devices. It will have apps that make it functional by itself as well as being a great quick interface to all your other Apple gear. Electronic wallet for credit, debit, and cash transfers. Most people have no idea how big this can be. In the U.S. alone credit and debit card interchange fees (the fees merchants pay to accept these payment forms) are on the order of 40 to 50 billion annually and almost pure profit for the banks and Visa and MC. Expect Apple to disrupt this market. I expect Apple to develop their own payment network. People will bank with Apple and use their iPhones and iWatches to pay for things. Automotive automation starting with Siri in cars. Whole home automation again using Siri. Siri is being ramped up quickly with vastly more intelligence. In a few year you will be able to talk to your house. There will be a common interface and nearly all appliance manufacturers will integrate with it. There are internet connected appliances now, but there is no overall control scheme. With Apple home automation you will be able to talk to and control all your appliances, lights, entertainment system, HVAC, etc. There will always be Apple haters, but with a nice intuitive interface & Siri you will be able to control most aspects of your modern life from anywhere. Topic.Title: Accounting gymnastics look questionable

Message.Msg: Need to change charter amd articles of incorporation raised this week. Is apple a manufacturer or bank, broker or dealer in securities? any company that trades $150B in securities w/o reporting trading loss or gain figures is lfar ess than transparent. A $150B question mark is very big for a company making $40B. a. Paragraph 8, as amended: Banks, brokers and dealers in securities, and other enterprises may carry securities and other assets in a trading account.3 Cash receipts and cash payments resulting from purchases and sales of securities classified as trading securities as discussed in FASB Statement No. 115, Accounting for Certainnvestments in Debt and Equity Securities, shall be classified pursuant to Statement 95 (as amended) based on the nature and purpose for which the securities were acquired as operating cash flows. Cash receipts and cash payments resulting from purchases and sales of other securities and other assets shall be classified as operating cash flows if those assets are acquired specifically for resale and are carried at market value in a trading account. Cash flows from purchases, sales, and maturities of available-for-sale securities shall be classified as cash flows from investing activities and reported gross in the statement of cash flows.
